No. 1S57 September. 1916. GENERAL STAFF INDIA. Scale 1 inch to 530 yards (approx) 5oo 0 M.Squares -p [Distances by Estimat/bn) Sketch of W. end of GURMAH SAFHA (accuracy not to be depended on) 5 4 ' 3 Z | T_ £>3fe Palms t A=Possible pos/l/on oF Mine Fie/ds B = Conspicuous s/aniinq ^ fa/m Vi-ee C = Z tmii of Vision From D D = Enemy's Gun Posit/on Date gardens on left bank drier and less cut up with irrigation chan nels than those on right bank, where there are also said to be two creeks about 20' broad and 5 feet deep. The clearing on the left bank renders troops moving near the bank of the GURU AH SAFHA visible from 'D' but observation is said to be avoid able by a slight detour through about 2' of water. Range from 'C' to 'D' estimated at 2600 yards. The gun position at 'D' is within SO yards of the river bank. ^ The 2 guns are said to be dose together and in line. L The Turks are reported by Arabs to have practiced with shell at the point of junction of the GURMAH SAFHA and ABU SHAH TAR, where a ship L coming up stream first becomes visible. Enemy observed were wearing light yellow uniform coats. Open Water of inundation FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'Sketch of W. end of Gurma Safha’

mods.abstract: Imprint:General Staff India.Distinctive Features:Sketch map issued as an ‘Appendix B (2) Serial No. 12 D 1’ to illustrate British military operations on the Euphrates River from 26 June to 25 July 1915. Shows the possible position of mine fields and enemy’s guns along River Euphrates with landmarks lettered for reference and explained in a key. Contains a descriptive note in the left centre.Map marked ‘For Official Use Only’.In the left-hand corner: ‘S.D.O. No. 1357, September, 1915’.Oriented with west to the top.
